ESTABLISHED 1880.
Riltor and Manager - - R. SHELLIEG
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFP.
WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 8, 1908:
SIR E- GORST'S SPEECH.

Sir Eldon Gorst’s speech at Khartoum must be regarded with satisfaction by all who have the interests of the Sudan at heart, inasmuch as we are informed that he stated that Lord Cromer'’s poli s to be upheld, and the lines of his Administatjonfollowed-as long as he (Sir Eldon Gorst) at the Agency. The development of the Sudan has been a remark ably rapid one, and-all the existing conditions point to a continuance of the expansion of its prosperity, and it is therefore of the utmost importance that-no obstacle should be placed in the way of its administfators at the present time. The note of the Financial Adviser set at rest the doubts as to the financial treat- ment which the Sudan was to receive under the new regime, but as the whole question of the Sudan and its administration is one of such intense importance to this country, it is just as well that. a definite line of policy should have been stated and it is relieving to find, that no departure from the conditions laid down by the late Consul General are to be made. When the size of the country is con- sidered, no less than the numberless tribes who come under the jurisdiction of the Sudan Government, the comparative smallness of the English and Egyptian staff which is employed in its administration is certainly remarkable. A few years since the country was seething in the throes of a savageand despotic Govern- ment under which the laws of might were alone respected, while to-day the lawless ad herents of that Government are the loyal and efficient soldiers of this, and even the tribes which inhabit the provinoes to the extreme south of the country are slowly, but none the less surely, being trained to the knowledge of the advantages of labour and its attendant results. Countries, like persons, are prone to forget the source from which their benefits have sprung So long as these be

nefits continue to exist without interrup- tion, and so it is that we hear frequent complaints as the sums of money which are occasionally voted (on loan at interest let it be membered) to the Sudan by the Egyptian ' Government, the authors this discontent | being apparently forgetful of . the ‘enormous extent to which Egypt has profited by the | works which haye been and are being, accom- | plished in the former country.

Take away the sdvantages thus gained -and we fancy that the critics of the moment would be.the'ffrst to condemn what they would be, only too ready to term short-sighted policy of a Government which had thus rendered useless the expenditure of thousands and the labour of years. Iti’ incredible that anyone who has the interest of this country before him, should be so fur ignoran€’ of the relation in which it stands “to the Sudan, as to advocate -the diminution of thé grants which are. necessary tothe. welfare of the Southern ,Dominion by even so mach as a small piastrs, and yet there are those who are apparently always ready to lift their voices in an incessant chorus of com- plaint, and prophecy ruin to Egypt if the granting of such loans is continued.

Such an attitude would be the more readily understood if there existed any single instance where money advanced to the Sudan ‘had been devoted to any purpose other ‘than to the most pressing reforms, but from the very first expenditure in the country we believe that every piastre hasbeen placed to the greatest possible advantage, and that no'single.reform has been undertaken but it was essential to the continued welfare of the country. The Sudanese are naturally a smart race and one which only requires a modicum of instraction, and this will perhaps account for the extraordinary success which has attended the efforts of the Government. to implant civilization in their country; even now when the people might with justice be supposed to retain many Of their former prejudices -as to their mode of life, it’ is astonishing to’ find how vety few cling to them, the spirit of emulation is ex- ceeedingly keen, not only among the younger men, but it,also touchés the remnants of the former “generation with the result that-the Spdanese bid fair.to attain to an intellectual level equal tothat of any African, race in a remarkably short space of time.

The Government is working steailily to the advancement of ‘its sphere of inflnenee, the natives ‘are being trained, to all the trades for which | there is any necessity in the country, and | the agricultural instinct, nullified to a great extent by the policy of the late Khalifa who considered it necessary to. employ all the able hodied men’ in his Swn body :guard, ‘is being fostered and en- couraged in every manner possible, mhile the formation and treatment ‘of the army ‘has met with results which perhaps were only to be expected, the Sudanese being natorally a lover of the display and glory which is an attribute toa soldier's life.

Take ail these points in review, ‘and it willbe seen that nothing but what ia bene- ficial having résulted from the policy adopted by Lord Cromer, it would be little less than ériminal to introduce any changes of impor- tance at,the present day, and we congratu- late Sir Eldon Gorst upon’ the decision. of upholding the-old methods of administration.

One of our contemporaries certainly is distinctly unhappy on the subject-however, and sets up a doleful wail because the new Consul General has seen fit to continue” the policy of the old, but ‘as. the mission of this paper appears to be that of inviting causes of complaint it is,doubtful whether it ever attempts to ‘reach the truth of things at all, or it would cheerfully” abandon the Sudan to the reign of such men as the Malidi or the Khalifa provided’ only that no English- man. wére allowed to. refain in the conntry.

However in a commendable desire to ob- tain the trath on at least‘dne point it inserts a postscript asking* for information regard- ing “the proposed campaign to Darfur” and d in reterence to this we. are in # position to inform it that there is to be no campaign to Darfar, neither has there been one proposed.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA’S MURDERS.
div.p: Some weeks ago an English sailor was mur- dered near Saint Catherine’s Square at Alex- andria. Sourouyan; who is accused of the crime, 4 will be tried'at the May sessions of the Helfenic ze Coort. The trial was to have taken place week, but as some essential witnesses did appear, it had to be postponed.

The enquiry held by the Italian Consolar Court into the subject of the recent murder of the advocate Volpini shows that the murderer, Massimiliano, acted with premeditation. The man, who accompanied the assassin to the law- yer’s chambers, is considered by the Consulate to have been an accomplice in the crime. The murderer and his accomplice, who are still at Hadra Prison, will shortly be sent to Ancona for trial, The~ “dossier” of 'the case has already been despatched to Italy.

The Natiye Parquet has bpened an enquiry into the murder.ot a Betberine in Old Bourse- street on Sunday evening, whose head was almost severed from his body by a young Greek. The Native Assjze Court at Alexandria has sentenced Mohamed Mousbaha Abou Shehid to penal servitude for lite for having murdered his diyoreed wife while she was being married to another man.
A correspondent writes : —

Now that so many of the chiefs of the Alex- andria Police have been transferred, it is to be | hoped that» active’ measures will be taken to prove the extraordinary mystery surrounding the assassination of Mr. Vivante in the sum- mer. Here the victin'was a well-known resi dent of Cairo snd he was killed in his bedroom ina hotel in the centre of Alexandria. It is very strange that the local detectives are absolutely nonplassed in this matter.

div.head: ACCESSION DAY
div.p: TODAY'S CELEBRATIONS.

To-day, on the occasion of the anniversary of the accession of H.H. the Khedive, Cairo bears a festive appearance. Everywhere are signs of rejoicing and loyalty to the throne. The prin- cipal streets of the Capital are gaily decorated with bunting, and the hotels, such as Shep- heard’s and the Grand Continental, have no small share in the scheme ot decoration.

The reception held by H. H. the Khetlive at Abdeen Palace this morning was more than -usually well attended, and the stream of car- riages conveying the Khedive’s distinguished visitors was a source of great interest to the tourists who happened to be on the route to the Palace, at the entrance to which a goard of honour was drawn up to pay the usual com- pliments to the members of the Diplomatic Corps.
At noon & salute of 21 guns was fired from the Citadelaind thé Polygon barracks, similar salutes being fired at Alexandria and Port Said.

This morning at 10.30 a.m. his Highness reviewed the Egyptian troops in Cairo on the Observatory parade ground at Abbassieh, and inthe evening a fete will be held at the Esbe- kieh Gardens in honour of the anniversary.
At Alexandria the anniversary is marked ‘by an abundant display of flags of all nations, the | ; Government departments: making a special show.

H. E. the Governor of Alexandria held an official reception at the Gouvernorat from 10 a.m. to noon, which was attended by the Gov- ernment civil and military officials, the Consu- lar Corps and a large number of ulema, nota- bles, and clergy of the city. The pupils of the Orwa El-Woska schools, with their bands, numbering fifteen hundred, paraded before the Governor, and then returned to Mohamed Aly- square,‘ where they played the Khedivial An- them in front of the statue of Mohamed Aly.
In the evening a banquet will be given by the Governor at the New Khedivial Hotel to the Government adminiatrative officials and a tiumber of notables of Alexandria.

The banquet will be attended by the follo- |; wing :— Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Beneducci Bey, Mr. Borchgrevink, M. E. Reman, Moh. Bey Saleh, Moh. Bey Mahfuz, Mr. Kiug Lewis, Rear Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, Dixon Bey, Gedge Pasha, Borton Bey, Dr. Schiess Pasha, Chataway Bey, Hopkinson Bey, Hafez Bey Mo- i hamed, Dr. C. M. Ekins, Sheehan Bey, Mr. Ehr- lich, Mr, Molesworth, Ismail Bey Hassanein, Ahmed.Pasha Yehia, Ahmed Pasha Ferid,. Sir Joseph Saba Pasha, Soliman Bey el Abani, Ahmed Bey Ayoab, Mansour Bey Youssouf, Ismail Bey el Bourai, Ibrahim Bey Haki, Ali Bey Huseein, Zananiri. Bey and Ahmed Bey Sid Ahmed.

We beg to tender our hearty congratulations to the Khedive of Egypt on the anniversary of his accession. On an occasion like the present it is both customary and opportune to pass in review the chief events of the sovereign’s reign. But such a survey would be inadequate without endeavouring to estimate the bearing ot such events upon the present situation and their probable influence on the future. The most im- portant of these events from this point of view, as standing out prominently from among the rest, andas calculated to make his Highness’s reign famous even in the lengthy roll of Egypt’s history, are the extension of her dominions by the restoration of her lost provinces in the Su- dan and the building of the Assouan Dani. The former has assured to this country durable peace upon her borders and bas manifested to the world at large the bravery and capacity of her soldiers when pitted against a most valiant. foe. But that brilliant feat of arms bas been ri- valled, if not sarpassed, by the greatest of en- gineering triumphs which the modern world has witnessed, and which must necessarily be chief amongst the factors contributing to her future prosperity. ‘These events, even if unaccompa- nied by many useful ameliorations in almost every department of the Administration, would | | be sufficient to lend lustre and distinction to his Highness’s -reign. At a moment like the present, one naturally asks oneself what are the main features of the era inaugurated by the accession of the Khedive, and the conclusion suggested is that coming ages will note this | epoch as a period of peaceful progress and pro- longed prosperity.
Called suddenly to the Throne at the . | age of eighteen, the Khedive was brought face to face witha most difficult situation.

He was on all sidés “surrounded by pitfalls. On the one hand there was‘a foreign occupation of his country and on the other native advisers of unscrapulous character and, fresh from the environment of Vienna, he was quite in- . | experienced ofthe intrigues and cabals, which ever beset an Oriental Court. But in addition to these perilous factors, the situation was complicated by the jealousy of Turkey, who . | eagerly desired that Egypt should fall again into her hands, and the rivalry and mutual hostility of the European Powers. Aby serious and sastained affort to set himself at variance with the occupying Power would have been fraught with the most disastrous consequences, not alone to the Khedivial dynasty, but might have led tothe shedding of Egyptian blood asa prelude to a Buropean conflict. The danger of such an attitude is plainly hint- ed-at by Lord Milner in his ‘England in Egypt,” who does not exaggerate ita dire possibilities. But despite his youth and con- sequent inexperience and the absence of capable advisers, his Highness has/ risen superior to all the intrigues. to which many a roler of matarer years, though less richly endowed with the qualities of firmness, courage, and discrimination, might very well have suo- cumbed. It is manifest to those who have

closely watched his Highness’s cateer that the dangers by which he was formerly surrounded are now entirely removed, and recent years have shown that the futare which awaits him has all the elements of permanent well-being and advancement.

The remarkable, nay exceptional, ability, with which His Highness grappled with the complex problem of dual government and proved himself equal to an abnormal situation, not of his own creation, merits high commend- ation The part he has hed to play has been one of the most delicate and embarrassing that could fall to the lot of any Sovereign and would have taxed the patience and sagacity of states- men of no mean order. That task has been to maintain his prestige and rightful position amongst his native subjects, whilst acting in deference to the advice tendered to him by ‘the British Government. Is there anyone, who, will venture to suggest that his endeavours in this direction have not been crowned with complete and conspicious success

His Highness’s solicitude for the welfare of his country, is evinced by his constant and never-failing attendance at the Council of Ministers and the active share taken by him‘in their deliberations. He is, in fact, his own Minister, “though holding himself rightly above faction and party. Not alone is he his own Minister, but he is his own Ambassador, as witness his visits to European Courts and to Turkey. By the sovereigns-of-Rurope ‘he is always received as a persona grata especially in England, where his relations with the Royal Family are of the most cordial. His liberal hospitality to foreign royal visitors, when they are his guests, and his frequent and friendly receptions, accorded to representatives of Foreign Powers accredited to this country, are eloquent testimony to his European sym- pathies.

It would be difficult to name an Oriental ruler, who takes a more absorbing interest in the development.of his country, than does the | } present holder of the Khediviate. The Mariout Railway would alone suffice to show the practical energy of his Highness, The line when extended to the Tripolitan frontier will one day become a solid, substantial, and effective link with the rest of the North African railway system, and is destined to become a great artery of traffic and to open cp a huge extent of country, which has been allowed to fall into complete neglect since the Arab conquest. of Egypt. His keen interest in agricultural pursuits, is evinced by the improved methods of hasbendry on his estates and the great care be bestows on the breeding of the finest cattle. This encouragement of agriculture is one of his chief claims to popular devotion. Egypt is essentially an agricultural country and agri- culture is.the greatest of all industries, because the fertility of the soil is an inxhaustible source of wealth. It is to the credit of His Highness that he has understood and given hiniself up to the study of agricultural questions in a way unrivalled by any other sovereign, except perhaps the founder of united Italy, the late Victor Emanuel, whose boast it was to. describe himself as King and cultivator. There is an advantage to a country, which has agriculture |* for its principle industry of a.description seldom alluded to. That is, a8 was pointed out by Aristotle, that it keeps the population away from politics, an inestimable blessing assuredly in a state like Egypt where cultivation is still in so backward a condition. This consideration as well as the healthier life enjoyed away from the towns, to which in the building of modal villages the Khedive has so. largely contri- buted, is probably present.to his ‘mind when by precept and example he. ever. inculcates the exploitation by the people themselves of Egypt’s most valuable asset.

If we have accurately gauged the situation and rightly cast the horoscope of coming events, there lies before His Highness Abbas II, a fature of such promise as may well be envied by many an ambitious potentate on the European continent, a future, indeed, which should amply satisfy the aspirations of one so practical in his aims and so reasonable in his desires.

It is the earnest hope of all true lovers’of this country that he may long be spared to devote his energies to the furtherance of Egypt’s advancement, to watch over her destinies and to assist her to attain to the position of foremost amongst Oriental nations.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA’S STREETS.
div.p: ‘To THe Eprror or THE “Eoyprian Gazerre.”

Sir—I spent a most pieasnrable hour or two recently in the Nouzha gardens, which are most enjoyable and long required, in fine a great boon to all residents. Would that the Municipality could see their way to: spend a small sum, which would be vastly less: than that spent oa the Nouzha gardens, in placing one or two of our small streets lying between Rue Cleopatra and the sea ina more sanitary condition by asphalting or paving. At present they are mere bye-lanes filled with filth and rubbish and can certainly not be considered sanitary. The area is only a small one, butit is very important to the inhabitants of the neighbourhood, and there are other areas re- quiring similar sanitation. This is a disgrace to the Municipality and should be immediately attended to, especially in view of the fact that we stand a risk of being visited by the chylera fiend, despite the laudable efforts which are being made to keep the disease out of the country by the Quarantine authorities,
Yours truly
CLEoMOHBEY.
Alexandria, January 6.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Waldemar of Prussia, who is arriving in Egypt shortly is the elder son of the Kaiser's brother, Prince Henry of Prussia. He was born at Kiel in 1889.
Sir Eldon Gorst'is not expected to retura tg Cairo before the 24th inst.

Dr, Rutherford, M.P,,” visited the British | Agenoy yesterday morning and was received ‘ by Mr. Ronald Graham. Daring Dr. Ratherford’s recent visit.to India he traversed enormous tracts of country and gathered a great deal ofinformation, which he intends to make use | ofin the: House of Commons.
The Greek Catholic.Patriarch of Egypt, Cyril VII, will shortly leave Cairo for Rome to attend the jubilee of Saint John Chrysostom.
The Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Alexandria, Photios I, who has been for some time in Cyprus in order to decide an episcopal diffi- culty in the autocephalons charch there, has returned to Egypt.
The Sultans Mohamed and Monssa Hamad, potentatés of the Messarieh and Forkieh tribes as well as many chiefs’ of Kordofan have been visiting Khartoum ‘in ordet to pay homage’ to Sir Eldon Gorst.

The two celebrated physicians, Mr. Mal- colm Morris, F.R.C.S., Edin. and Dr.St. Clair Thomson M.D, P.R-C.P., Lond, etc., have been spending their Christmas holiday in Cairo. The former is the well-known special- ist on skin. diseases .and tuberculosis, once President of the Harveian Society, and also in 1899 the representative ot the National association ét the Berlin Congress for the pre- vention of tuberculosis. Dr. St. Clair‘ Thomp- son’s speciality is the throat; and in addition to the various other appointments he holds in London he'is also a member, of the “Aca- demia Medica” of Florence, the American Laryngological Association,” and the “Société Francaise de Laryngologie.” He is responsible for many learnéd publications, on the throat and: nose’ and is European editor of “The Larynago scope.”

Captain and Quartermaster "W. Jobnson, 8rd Coldstream Guards, Mrs.Johnaon, Lieu- tenant G. E. Ferguson. R'A:M.C. and Miss ‘Tripp, Q.A.LN.S. are leaving for England on : the 12th instant by the 8.8. “Plassey.”

Sheikh Hassouna El] Nawawi, the Chancel or of Al-Azhar University has sent in his resigna- tion to the Khedive. His resignation is not yet ~ accepted. It is probable the Chancellor will be granted an audience to-day by the Khedive in connection with this matter.

div.p: The board of examination appointed by the Ministry of the Interior ‘to examine the stud- ents of the school of Veterinary Medicine as- sembled under the Presidency of Mr. Grabam Director General of the Department of Public Health’ from 27th to 31at December 1907 and examined the students of the above school with the following results. :—

Rageh Effendi Girgis, Sabil Effendi Bishara, Salech Effendi Kamel, Amin. Effendi Suliman, Mr/F. Ghirga passed the final examination and obtained their diplomas. Abd el Majid Effendi Bahgat, and Ali Effendi Selim passed the Ist examination and are transferred to the second years course.

div.head: PERSIANS ‘AT CAIRO.
div.p: A telegram has been received from Teheran by the Persian colony at Cairo announcing the dismissal of their Consul General, Mirza Aly, Khan, and the appointment of Hay Meriza Mouna Khan, in conseqtience of the com- plaints of the Persians at Cairo against the former.

div.head: A TURKISH MYSTERY:
div.p: A few days ego a young Gréek lady, an Ottoman subject, arrived ‘gt Alexandria from Constantinople. Her father had been & doctor to the Sultan and he lately disappearpd and is supposed to have been murdered. As the lady is well ¥ersed in many of the secrets of Yildiz the Torkish authorities have sent to Alexandria ‘to bring her back, but up now her whereabouts are absolutely unknown.

Both in Cairo and in-Paris it waa fally recognised from the outset that Mr. Lecomte’s name was most tnwarrantably dragged into this unpleasant affair by Herr | Harden.

div.head: CAIRO CONCERT SOCIETY.
div.p: The programme of the fourth concert was hardly equal to that of its predecessor, in depth, and’ one might say, emotion, yet it was most interesting. Berlioz overture to the “Car- naval Romain,” a ¢urious and delightfully descriptive piece, the ‘Pastoral’ of cou the prelude to the 8rd act of “T'ris'ai three’pieces are well worth hearing: The pleas- ing “Sylvia” ballet, and Chabriers clever “tout | de force”, “Espatia”, formed an admirably set- off was well given, and its variety of melodies and eftects adequately realised. The “Pastoral” was hardly a success. The calm and distinctness it should have, were lost, the ‘‘Andante” ' was taken far‘two quickly and noisily. All the impression «of rustic peace and ty was blurred. The last two movements. were not well accentuated, their distinctive points and transitions were not sufficiently marked. The “Délibés” ballet was well enough played. It is pretty, but rather of thé nature of casino or park band music and there is, perhaps, too much of it. The “Tristan” was quite* good, only the horn seemed. nervons and anxious to hurry through his solo. He missed the far away plaintive pathos of those exquisite trill- ing phrases. The ‘“‘Espafia is a most interest- ing’ piece of polyphong. One would almost call it a series’ of layers, one theme super- imposed nother, the instruments-answering and over-riding each other in a quaint and rather effective fashion. It was perhaps the best item as far as concerned its execu- tion. All its changés and episodes were clearly marked and properly emphasized For next Sunday we can only count definitely on three items, Saint Saéns septett, Haydn’s “Surprise” and the “Walkiiren-Ritt”. The two other items, “Sylvia” and the ‘Tchaikowsky March” figured in this last. and the previous concert. We may hope for the much-delayed “Forest Marmurs” as One.suppleméntary item.

div.head: NOISY CAIRO.
div.p: To tHe Editor or THE “Eaypriaw Gazette.”

Sir,—The casual visitor to Cairo cannot fail tobe struck by the fact that for its size it is the noisiest town in existence.Coachmen crack their whips inthe ears of the passer-by. Street vendors yell their wares with a persistency, which is truly surprising, carts, of 4, design which would. disgrace the days of Noah, rattle along with’ their loads of stone or building material, and to add to the pandemonium of formér days, there is now the horn echoing pérpetually in almost every. street.o Cairo,

For a motor carthey are supposed to beindis- pensible, and they. aré certainly to be preferred to the whistle of one enterprising motorist, who rushes his ear through. the streets, iwith his, whistle in fall blast, regardless-ag to whether there-is traffic in the way or not. Bat the use of these ‘horrible inventions in place-of the old bieycle bell is a practice which should be stamped out by law. Not only are they: nerve shattering, they are a cause of absolute danger tothe pedestrian, who looks wildly round ina search for a motor car, which is not,there, with his imminent risk of being ran over by. the bicyole which he has not noticed. A. mano 4; to'use the title for courtesy, was observed thia morning riding his machine bebind another cyclist The street was empty, saye for these two and yet the hindérmost kept his horn busy with its discordant notes, until the foremost rider reduced his pace to a minimum: in order. to let the-othar pass him. Bat it was all of no avail, The owner of the horn.was evidently out to enjoy himself and hepreserved his position until the other stopping he was forced to pass and continued his way, still at bia infernal work until he waa lost sight of.

I am nota vindictive man bat I must confeas that it would give me unbounded pleasure to hear that this’ gentleman had met with a serious accident,or had been compelled. to keep on blowing hishorn through the night, in order-that he might realize what'the sound of it was really like. Can the Authorities do nothing in this. matter, for Cairo is rapidly becoming almost unlivable by reason of. its street noises.
Yours ete,, Tus Listener.
Cairo, January, 6th.

div.head: “THINGS THAT NO (EUROPEAN) FELLOW CAN UNDERSTAND.”
div.p: To the Editor pr THE “Eayprian Gazerre.”

A few years ago a correspondent cal- led the attention of your readers to a few of the anomalies of modern Egyptian civilisation as practised at Alexandria; of such were the usé of the feet in carpentry; the stabling of horses with their heads outwards; and, last but not least, the adoption by the Tramway Company of the red flag asa token of safety, and of the green one as danger signal ; whilst it-was the practice of the wattman to endeavour to remove obstucles from the line of rails by charging them at full speed, with a grand display of fireworks, to the terror of lady passengers. Of all these peculiarities and many others, he said, there was but one all sufficient explanation givén to’ the enquirer ; “Qosa vuole signore, noi siamo in Egitto?”

Another anomaly in, a city grhere:the strag- gle of the classes for wealth and of the masses for existence becomes keener every hour, is the apparent indifference of all to the time of day except that indicated by the. bang of the midday gun. It is but a few years since-the first timekeeper in Egypt available to the pu blic was placed at the Bourse end of the Alexandrian square. Bat the utility of this innovation has not, yet, been sufficiently re- cognized to encourage: either our local bene- factors or the “Patres Conscripti” to extend it to other.parts of the city

Mote recently, the convenience of a reliable striking clock, visible to shipping at the quays, and to arriving passengers, to whom the chances of catching a train to the capital are’ sure to be a matter of primary interest, was; at once, recognized by the able and energetic Diteotor’} General of Castoms on taking offiges He, | doubtless, at the same time bad iw view the} necessity. for instilling punGtualityy into-the } minds of his subordinates: as -well as those:of: persons having business _ appointments: with himself, ‘The. value of the Custom: House clock has. been fully: appreciated: by merchants and travellers, if not, perhaps, by all thosefor | whose profit it-was intended : but clock towers ate, nevertheless, conspicuous by their absence from our city.

What contrast to the peagefal towns and villages-of the Austrian Tyrol, where. autumn and winter, in the beautiful cities of Innsbruck and Salaburg, ate passed as tranquilly: as the flow of the: picturesque rivers through their midat, And yet, at every ture, the traveller's gaze is met by a lofty quadrangular tower, having on’ each. face- an. ornamental clock: of such dimensions that‘those:who: run may-read; and be reminded of the fitting -moments'te be turned’ to account for the’ benefit of: their fellow toilers in this breathing world ;- while bells and chimes, at frequent intervals,euggest repentance to the sinner, ere it be too late; and the daily worshipduetohis Creator: Here, ii busy Cottonopolis, there seems-to be no desire on the part ofthe residents for such infalatle rentinders ‘of their duty: towards God ‘and theirnsigh- bour, and of a fature existence in & better world. Their detractors-go 60 faras\te‘saythat; during six days out of the obveny Overy moment

is devoted with feverish ardour tp sdorstion of the “Dio def or del ‘mondo Signor,” whatever creed they may profess.on the seventh when compounding for the idolatry of the past week. Happily, if this she true | of isome,! the: bright exceptions are far too numerous and conspi- cuons for the above to be accepted as having any but a very “restricted'application to oar generally pious fellow citizens.

Another anomaly ’is ‘the liberality towards the publie of antimpecanions Municipality'in a gratuitous iétalage of* its* art’ "treasures. What ‘a" revenae' might: be obtained “froma periodical exhibition, at P.T. 5 per head; of the items of thosenepleadid..collections of pictures by local:masters, now constantly on view “gratis” in the galleries of the Rues Rosette and Chérif Besha,., to eay nothing of, the gems so lavishly.displayed, at intervals, slong the road. to Ramleh. The poor exhibi- tors, however, doubtless, have to pay, in these hard times, forthe privilege. of delighting the éyes andelevating the minds of those capable ‘of appreciating. the pitch: of excellenoe.,in ! artistic skill to which our Alexandrian Raphaela, id. Rubens’ have. attained .in.the ;days ; ot tian progress.

It seems strange, two, that. the Corporation, reputedly desirous of adding to its pecuniary resources, does not take a leaf out of the pages of the “Thunderer” with its enoyclopediss dictionaries, atlasses, and . book. club, and add to its picture, galleries some’ réclame ilustrations of. its, unearthed archmological lions.

Views of the~contents of Dr. Breccia’s Museum, of.the Serapéum and Pompey’s Pillar galleries, and, of the wonderful eleatric lighted Bgypte-Roman tomb should lead to a con- siderable increase’ in-the number, of: visitors. ‘The senators, too, might show. their wisdom (while we wait. for some means of carriage cir. culation bythe New Quay to the Palace of Ras el Tin,, and,the long promised Corniche road to Bamleh) by placings Municipal version, in poster type, of a popular ditty.(parodied by Mr. Jarley, of fertile imagingtion and. waxwork fame) in the hands of every tourist.visiting our shores as follows.
If I know’d an arbagi what would’nt go With trippers to see my Shogifa Show, D’ye think I’d license-him ?
Oh! no, no!
Then drive to Johnny's!
The above are only,a few of the-things at Alexandria that no fellow. as. stupid as Iam can understand ;, but nowmore'at present from.
Yours,
Dunpreary.
Alexandria, 4th January

div.head: ZIZINIA. THEATRE.
div.p: MADAME BUTTERFLY:”

Althongh only: prodaced four-years ago at the Scala,” and strange as it-now appears, but coldly received throughout, -and applauded: by a small ‘minority, “Madame- Butterfly” has at last become a-universal-favorite

Poceini has ofcourse-made many changes in | certain passages and elimicated, entirely, por- tions of the original composition,‘ but even these alterations did not-prevent failure-of-the opera for some two years.

The adverse criticism of the original com- position was entirely-due. to. the composer's doubtful prudence: in. introducing practically . | identical passages and effects as in “Boheme” and’ “Manon.” Even;now-one hears an oc- casional bar, or two of one or other of these. It is, however, as it stands, without doubt a very meritorious work-and the many delightful me- lodies and harmonies with which it abounds e | succesafally tided it, over its, original mis- fortone.

The dramatic partion of.the opera is centred entirely.on. Madame Butterfly. herself. (Cio-Cio, San). Butterfly is:simplicity. itself, an embodi- ment ofaffection,and devotion ; the passion is her state ofrbeing; ont of it she has no exist- | ence; and, alas, poon little Butterfly she. be- comes the confiding toy. ofia. thoughtless youth, eventaally, ending.,her. life, in.an agony, of jealousy..and despair.

In the title réle last, evening Signorina Salo. o}mea Crusceniski gave a_.well-nigh., perfect interpretation of;the, character. and; kept, her sudience, in . entire.sympathy, ) Both, from «a musical.and dramati point..of. view her per. formance. was highly axtistio .: This .was fortun- ate, for.on-Batterfly rests.the,snccess or failure of the opers We-compljsmentSignorins Crusce- niski on our, being able ..to say, that. there, was certainly. no sign.of failoredast;eyening. Signo. rina Margherita Julia also deserves. much | praise for her excellent work:.in the character of the. servant Suzuki.

Signor Italo Cristalli created.a good impres. sion’ as Pinkerton, hig numbers.being, effective: ly-sung. Sharpless, the. American Conanl, wes well supported by Signory Nunzio Rapisardi. There is howayer very little opportunity..\for |! the male charactars.in.the ,opara,, The chores wash trifle ragged.in. the first.act, but an excal- lent rendering was.given,of the, hidden charas, which forms the rather, pathetie..ending, of the second act, and was very deservedly encored. desited and the orchestra. under the baton of “ Signor Zucaapi was, as usual, excellant.

FOOTBALL.
6th DRAGOONS v. INNISKILLING FUSELIERS.

After defeating the-Coldstreams on Friday by a goalto nil, the Battalion team of-thedn+ niskilling Pasiliers*met and defeated-the tir Inniskilling Dragoons’ by 3. goals to 1 at the Slade” Ground, Abbsssia last Saturday after- noon. There-was a large crowd-lining the ropes as the teams took the field. Panctually at-3 o'clock the Dragoons started against what little wind there was and immediately assumed..the aggressive. The.opposing backs were nobte be denied and the ball travelled to Welsh;: but being tackled he passed to Lyons: who with s beautiful shot netted the leather in the-cornet- The Dragoons pressed and a nice dribble by the forwards transferred play to the visiting goal where the excellent ‘defensive combination of of the backs stood the regiment in good stead and danger was averted Give and take’play then ensued until a fine run and shot by’ Hey almost equalized matters. Shortly: before ‘half time, the Inniskilling bucks got in motion and Lieutenant Anley, gaining; possession. from a pass’-by' Greer.went down the field.at+a great pacednd evading: the opposition, seored the: second point with a low shot. ‘Stung by'the’se- cond reverse, the Dragoons went away ata great pace and,e-beautiful.shot-by-Sitimaer just grazed the bar.
Half-time: Inniskalling: Fusiliers +2; Dra- goons O

Immediately after thé commiehctment: of*}* the second? half, the “Skins” attacked with’ splendid dash and combination and were with- |, in an ace of scoring, when Hay and Wood~ worth came to the rescue and turned the balls}: into touch. Erom the throw-in-Hey got posses- sion and eludingethe backs scored witha nice shot in the ‘corner. Play then: settled down in mid field for some tew minutes-until the ball rolled into touch. From the'throw-in'Robinson was just gettingnioely away when he Wasfouled’}* by Arthors, Brepbhan took the pesulity and with a fast shot-scored the third goal. The Dra- goons again attacked, Hey being noticeable for some excellent work. Try as. they would the Dragoons couldenot, penetrate, thedefence of Robingsoniand Cor which was the featnre of the game, the Inniskilling Fusiliers thus winning by 3 goals to 1
The display of Lyons was much‘ admired, also that of Liewtenaht Abley and Walsb. For the Dragoons Arthurs, Hay, and Williamson were the most prominent.

The Gonsalate will'-be open daily from 10 a.m: till noon for thie delivery Of registration certificates.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways
div.p: NOTICE.
Public Auction in Cairo Goods Shed of\ Unclaimed Articles _ (time-expired).
On. the 20th January, 1908, and following days, at 9.30 a.m. sharp,.a Public Auction will be held in the Cairo: Goods Shed “of all time- expired, unclaim@i articles, amongst which are the following:
Empty Sacks, Coal; Wrought ron, Flour, - Confectionery, ,Clothing, Wines and Spirits, Preserved and Dry Fruit, Oil, Cereals, Wood, unworked and worked, Tibn, Miscellaneous, Unginned Cotton.
CONDITIONS OF SALE
1. Articles will be sold-separately or in lots, at the discretion of the Administration
2. (Purchasers must.pay cash for everything they’buy, immediately after the'lot or article is. sold
3. Articles must be removed immediately they are paid for
4. Purchasers thust-satisfy themselves as to the condition of articles befofe bidding, as no objection will be admitted after the goods are sold
5. Articles, which are not removed immed- iately they are paid for will be put up again and re-sold at the risk of .the fitst purchaser
6. The Administration reserves the right to withdraw from the sale any articles even aitap adjudication.
Cairo, 6th January, 1908.

The Egyptian Salt & Soda Co Ltd,

Notice is hereby given that at the Eighth Ordinary General Meeting of the Company held on Monday December 30th. 1907, the payment of a final Dividend of 2 % making a | total of 654 for the year, was approved. Coupon N° 8 will be payable at the rate of 19 1/2 Milligmes per share on and after the 15th. instant, at the Offices of the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo, Alexandria and London,
By. order Atuister J. Lowe Secretary to the Board Alexandria 7th. January 1908.
The Egyptian Salt & Soda Co. Ltd.

Messieurs les Actionnaires de |’Egyptian Salt and Soda Co Ltd. sont informés que par décision prise 4 l'Assemblée Générale tenne au Caire le Lundi 30 Décembre 1907, un divi- dende aoe de 19 1/2 Milliémes par action soit 2%, faisant un total de 6 0/0 pour l’année, leur sera payé 4 partir da 15 Janvier 1908 aux Caisses de la National Bank of Egypt, au Caire, 4 Alexandrie et 4 Londres contre remise du Coupon N” 8,
Par ordre Atuister J. Lows Secretary to the Board Alexandrie le 7 Janvier 1908,
Egyptian Constructions Ltd,
We beg to inform the public that tne Mark G. Boyes Branch has severed its connection with this Company as from the 28 December 1907.
All amounts owing by this Branch will now be paid direct by Egyptian Constructions Ltd. and all sums due to the Coy must be paid to the Company direct.
Egyptian Constructions Ltd.
We beg to inform the public that the Grant Bondi & Chinn Branch has severed its connection with this Company as from the 28 December 1907.
All liabilities of this Branch will be. dis- charged by Messrs. Grant Bondi & Chinn & all amounts due to this Branch must ‘be paid to Messrs. Grant Bondi & Chinn direct.
Egyptian Delta Light Railways Limited.

div.head: Notice to Advertisers
div.p: The “Egyptian Gazette” has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt any monovoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are received at the offices of the ‘Gazette’ from advertisers direct.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Les possesseurs de bicycles, tricycles, moto- cycles et voitures 4 main, y compris les orgues de barbarie, sont informés que des plaques nu- mérotées leur seront délivrées gratuitement a la Municipalité.
A coux qui ontdéja la plaque numérotée pour les bicycles, tricycles et motocycles il sera ajou- té une marque distinctive pour 1908.
Iis deyront se présenter au Service des Re- cettes jusqu'au 31 Janvier 1908, dimanches et jours fériés exceptés, pour fixer les plaques ou les marques distinctives & leurs véhicules.

Pasaé ce délai, tous les véhicules précités qui circuleront sans plaqueow la marque distinctive, donneront lieu 4 l’encontre de leurs possesseurs aux poursuites administratives prévues par le réglement.
Alexandrie, le ler Janvier 1908.
L’ Administratear, 31666-3-2 W. P. Cuaraway.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjadication la four- niture de 12000 métres carrés de dalles pour chaussée.
Le cautionnement est fixé a L.E 520.
Le cahier des charges est déposé¢ au bureau Technique ob il peut @tre consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9h. 4 midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront @tre adressées sous pli cacheté & Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Manicipalité avant le 4 Février 1908.
Elles pourront également étre Géposées en | séance de la Délégation le méme jour A/ 5 h. p.m,
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la men- tion : “Soumission pour fourniture de Dalles.”

Le cautionnement ou le regu d'une banque, d’aprés les conditions du cahier des charges, devra étre remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l’ouverturée des offres et au plus tard le 4 Février 1908 a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée,
Alexandrie, le 2 Janvier 1908 L’'Administrateur 31657-3-3 (Signé) W.P. Cuataway.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Service pes Recerres

Dans le courant da mois de Janvier de | chaque année, tout possesseur d'animaux et | | véhicules prévus par l’arrété du 21 Oct. 1905, | doit faire personnelicment la déclaration des | animaux et véhicules qa’il posséde, sous peine | d’ane double imposition @ titre d’amende
Cette déclaration devra @tre faite de la ma- | niére suivante :
Elle portera sur tous les animaux et véhi- | Icales que le possesseur posaéde poor ia pre | miére fois

Si cette premiére déclaration est déj4 faite, | Vobligation du possesseur se bornera, par scite, | & aviser la Manicipalité, dans le délai précité, des changements survenus dans le nombre on | la nature des animaox et véhicules déclards
Il n’y aura pas lieu de renowveler la déciara- tion si aucun changement n'est survena
Pour les animaux et vébieoles recus dans le courant de l'année, le possesseur en devra éga- lement, sous la méme peine, faire la déclaration dans les dix jours de la réception

A partir du premier février de chaque année | aura lien un recensement en yuede vérifier | exactitude des déclarations des contribuables, | sans préjadice da it de la Municipalité | de réitérer ses vérifications & toute époqne de l'année.
iministratenr *, CHATAWAY 31638-3-3.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le Mercredi S-Janvier 1908 de 10 heures du matin 4 midi, la Municipalité procddera | 4 la vente aux enchéres publiques prés de la j Porte Rosette d’une quantité de pierres (Kan. | taris, Moéllons, Dekchoum) provenant de la | démolition des fortificatione Sud.
Ces pierres sont divisées en lots de 20 & 100 M3.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d’en- chére de 1 %-et déposer le! 10 % dela. valear de la marchandise achetée an momentde la vente et effectaer le paiement intéyral 4 la Caisse Monicipale le lendemain du jour de Vadjudication,

Ils auront 4 supporter les droits de carriére au profit de la Villeet devront enlever les pierres acthetées dans un délai de dix. jours sous peine de folle enchére pour compte de l'adjudicataire et de perte du dépdt de 10 %.
L' Administratear ‘Signé” W. P. Onataway. Alexandrie, le 8 Janvier 1908. 81670-8-3

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration a l’honneur de porter & la | connaissance du public qu'elle recevra jusqu’su Seize Janvier 1908, 4 midi’ au plus tard, des offres poer la fourniture de 300000 (trois cent milles) Coins eu Bois de Sant identiques aux spécimens déposés au Bureau Central du Service de la Voie au Caire et qui peavent étre examinés chaque jour de neuf heures da matin & une heare p.m., les vendredis et jours fériés exceptés, Les soumissionnaires doivent envoyer avec leur offre un échantillon des Coins qu’ils proposent de fournir, et indiquer dans leur offre ’Atelier ot: les Coins seront fabriqués.

Ces Coins doivent étre faits et livrés confor- mément aux clauses et conditions du Cahier des Charges dont on peat obtenir un exemplaire au Service Central des Magasins & Boulac (Caire) et aux Magasins de Gabbary (Alexan- drie) chaque jour aux heures ci-dessus” indi- quées, les dimanches et jours fériés’ exceptés, contre paiement de cent milliémes.

Pour étre admis 4 conoourir, le soumiasion- naire devta Verser, au préalable, 4 une des Caisses de l'Administration, une somme de L.B. 20 (Livres Egyptiennes vingt) & titre de dépét provisoire, Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jus- montant de la valeur de Ja commande et cea | dans les vingt quatre heures & dater de l'avis de l'acceptation de son offre.

Les offres doivent étre accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente milliémes ainsi qve du recu constatant le versement du | dépét provisoire ; elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé a :
Monsienr le Directeur Général des Chemins | de Fer de l'Etat, Caire (Egypte)

et sous double enveloppe, |’intérieure pertent | la suscription suivante - “Offre pour foarniture de coins en bois.” L’ Administration ne s’engage pas a accepter | | l'offre la plus basse ni a donner suite aux | i | sourpissions présentées Elle se réserve le droit | | de diviser la commande.
Le Caire, le 27 Décembre 1907.

Il contient des revues completes et impartisles du coton, des graines de coton, eet du marche des caleurs; les derneieres statistiques jusqu'a la veilie de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des depeches officielle envoyens a la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
